column2: Towards the end of Winter Retreat 2018, Tan Suhajjo and the Abhayagiri Community ask Ajahn Pasanno questions related to monastic life.

column3: 2018-03-28 The Relationship Between Study and Practice.mp3
column6: The Relationship Between Study and Practice
Foundations, Community, Rebirth, Nibbana
Question text
The Buddha described his teaching as Dhamma-vinaya. Can you explain why it wasn't just Dhamma? What does this term mean?

In order to come to the training as Westerners, we often had to not follow cultural traditions and authorities. Monastic life has so many rules and the traditions are well established. How do we switch gears?
How do we expand our faith into other aspects of training?
Is vinaya about taking responsibility for your actions and mental states and how that affects other people?
Can you talk about skillful means to become more sensitive to the nuances of monastic training?
Can you talk about respect in the context of horizontal and vertical relationships in monastic life?
Are their multiple levels of brahmacariyƒÅ (celibacy)?
Can you speak to the development of respect for the symbols of monastic life as opposed to respect for individual teachers?
I notice that you sometimes don't react to the seemingly disrespectful behavior of visitors.
Western culture seems to have no context for celibacy as a good thing.
